US MARKET WRAP 13 April 2018: Investors take risk off the table ahead of potential geopolitics over the weekend
content:
* SNAP-SHOT: Stocks down, USD flat, treasuries flat, oil up
* REAR-VIEW: Waiting US decision on Syria, NAFTA updates, Weak Uni of Michigan report, Fed’s speak
* AHEAD: BoC Rate Decision, RBA Minutes, Canada CPI, UK CPI

* GEOPOLITICS: Whilst markets await for an upcoming strike, the US Ambassador for the UN Haley reported Trump has not yet made a decision over the plan of action on Syria whilst the US Pentagon warned that US military assets have entered the Mediterranean area, positioning the USS Winston Churchill into the sea. Amid expectations of an imminent attack, the UN Chief Guterres warned deadlock Security Council could lead to full-blow military escalation. In late trade, the US State Department expressed confidence that Syria’s government is responsible for the chemical weapons attack. Elsewhere, the Russian Deputy PM stated counter measures on the US will come once the full impact of US sanctions on Russia are analysed.

* TRADE WARS: On the NAFTA front, Mexico Trade Representative Kalach noted the deal contingency is dependent upon the political will from the Trump’s administration, pointing out that 5/6 demands from the US are bad for Mexico. US Commerce Secretary Ross appeared optimistic on reaching a deal, in principle, on NAFTA, possibly in the third week of May; if no accord is reached by the Mexican election, deal unlikely to be reached until the end of the year. Separately, China said to stall key M&A deals amid trade negotiations with the US, citing Qualcomm and Toshiba.

* FED SPEAK: Fed's Rosengren (non-voter, hawk) suggested that somewhat more tightening than the FOMC forecasts might be needed. As a reminder, he has previously hinted he is in the four-hike camp whilst the current FOMC median projections (March) remain for three hikes in 2018. Emphasis fell on its own economic forecast which called for an even more pronounced decline in the unemployment rate, given his expectation that cyclical strength in labour force participation will provide only a partial offset to solid gains in payrolls. Finally, he warned the Fed must consider risks to the outlook. Fed’s Bullard (non-voter, dove) noted the lower than expected Q1 GDP growth will not have an impact on the medium-term outlook, adding there is currently too much of uncertainty around trade tariffs to assess its impact.

* DATA: University of Michigan confidence data missed expectations in April, and the inflation expectations metrics slipped; analysts were quick to attribute the disappointing print on the stock market correction in February. March’s spike also led some to expect some paring back. JOLTs data was also a miss, with job openings falling by more than expected in February after January’s record high, while the quits rate was unchanged. Analysts said the data continues to indicate that labour market conditions remain tight.

* EQUITIES: SPX -0.29% at 2656, NDX -0.42% at 6628, DJI -0.50% at 24360  SECTORS: CONS CYC (XLY): -0.57%, CONS NON-CYC (XLP): +0.50%, ENERGY (XLE): +1.10%, FINANCIALS (XLF): -1.55%, HEALTH CARE (XLV): -0.08%, INDUSTRIALS (XLI): -0.24%, MATERIALS (XLB): -0.10%, TECH (XLK): -0.33%, TELECOMS (XTL): -0.15%, UTLITIES (XLU): +0.69%. 
Overnight equity futures took out yesterday’s highs rising to 2680 just before the cash open, when the gains were reversed and the EMINI faded back down. Further pressured by softer University of Michigan and JOLTS data was seen, with the EMINI returning to the 2650 area, a level that was revisited plenty of times this week.
Despite earnings for three major financial names today (JPM, Citi, Wells – all beating the top and bottom line), the sector closes red on Friday, with the financial sector underperforming. Energy was the outperformer, supporting the SPX for the session on the back of higher oil prices. Apart from the financial earnings, the main story stock specific stories today surrounded chip names, Qualcomm (QCOM) & Broadcom (AVGO), with the latter announcing a $12bln share repurchase programme after market on Thursday, and the former reportedly looking to become private in the next few months according to sources. M&A news was relatively light compared to recent sessions, where the focus was on Mylan (MYL) reportedly in advanced negotiations for German Merck’s KGaA (MRK GY) consumer health unit, sources suggest the bidding value is around $3.5bln.
Leading the S&P today was Alaska Air (ALK) following its March traffic report, and one of the laggards being PNC Financial (PNC) following earnings which EPS matched analyst expectations, but revenues missed.

* CRUDE: WTI (May) settles 32 cents higher at USD 67.39 per barrel and Brent (June) settles 56 cents higher at USD 72.58 per barrel. Crude put in a solid performance this week, rising to fresh multi-year highs, and taking out strong resistance above $66/bbl. This month’s OPEC and EIA reports erred on the bullish side, and on Friday, the IEA own monthly report said non-OPEC supply would grow by 1.8mln BPD (unchanged from prev.) in 2018, global oil demand growth also remains unchanged. IEA also said that OPEC oil production was down 200k BPD in March to 31.83mln BPD on Venezuela and Africa, while compliance with output deal reached 163%. But the most supportive factor for the crude complex was on geopolitical tensions – with a likely imminent strike on Syria stole the headlines, Yemen upped missile attacks into Saudi, which has some analysts more concerned. This week, Baker Hughes reported oil rigs rose by 7, the second straight week of rising rigs.

* TREASURIES: US 10yr T-Notes futures settle half-a-tick higher at 120-15+. Treasury yields were little changed on Friday with most action in the short end of the curve where 2yr yields rose to fresh (almost) decade highs. The rise in 2yr yields resulted in further flattening of the 2s10s and 2s30s curves (by around 3pbs). Treasuries were generally fulfilling their haven role, inversely moving to the direction of equities – particularly so after weak US data. Elsewhere, ahead of next week’s auction of 5yr TIPS, the US Treasury has asked primary dealers opinion on increasing 5yr TIPS issuance in the second half of the year.

* FOREX: DXY ended a tough week off worst levels, but still below the 90.000 axis and considerably weaker than it was prior to last Friday’s NFP report that missed consensus on the headline payroll count. The China vs US import tariff stand-off, Syria and Russian sanctions have largely dominated risk sentiment and directed moves in the broad Dollar with little on the data front to provide impetus as CPI was more or less in line with consensus. Hawkish FOMC minutes did give the Greenback a relatively modest lift, but a charm offensive between the US President and his Chinese counterpart was arguably equally supportive (for the Greenback and improved investor appetite for risk in general). However, this all paled into comparison vs a Trump tweet alleviating concerns about an imminent strike against Syria, which was only partly offset by Russia unveiling a list of counter-sanctions vs the US. The index around 89.800 vs a circa 89.355 low on Wednesday. AUD/NZD/CAD: the AUD was Friday’s stand-out commodity bloc and G10 outperformer, but all 3 have been big net winners on the week on a mixture of the aforementioned improving risk climate, data and CB leads, plus flows and re-positioning. AUDUSD eventually hurdled some major barriers in the high 0.7700s, with stops tripped above 0.7780 to a multi-week high just shy of 0.7810 and the next upside tech levels from 0.7812-15 (former a Fib and latter the 200 DMA). The Kiwi has challenged resistance at the psychological 0.7400 level several times, and got closest when the AUDNZD cross slipped under 1.0500 amidst the height of US-China trade tensions, but has pulled back amidst the AUD short squeeze and paring back of heavily oversold positions. However, the Loonie has starred overall this week, with USDCAD down from almost 1.2820 on Monday to around 1.2550 at one stage on positive NAFTA deal prospects, some firmer than forecast data, an upbeat BoC business survey and sharp rally in oil prices. However, the BoC is not expected to be prompted into (hike) action as soon as next week. The bullish April story continues, but GBP also got a boost from BoE hawk McCafferty who underscored his dissenting vote for a hike with a warning to the MPC not to delay any further, as expectations for a 2nd tightening in May topped 90%. The Pound also received some good news on the Brexit front via reports that EU’s Barnier could be will to offer the UK more flexibility on the timing to agree transition terms. Cable almost hit 1.4300 vs the 2018 high so far at 1.4345, while EURGDP finally breached 0.8700 to trade down to 0.8625 or thereabouts. A bearish week for the EUR overall vs major rivals, and largely due to dovish/cautious ECB minutes that more than counterbalance the hawkish lone or at least personal view of Nowotny. EURUSD  faded after a few attempts at 1.2400 and needs to close above the 21 DMA at 1.2323 to avoid re-visiting recent lows on the 1.2200 handle. USDJPY rallying through the key 107.50-55 area that has been capping the pair and threatening 107.90 resistance before 108.00. USDCHF and EURCHF also on an upward trajectory, though the Franc remains decoupled from usual/traditional safe-haven and risk correlations amidst capital outflows (Russian repatriation touted) and spec about official intervention. Finally, softer than forecast Norwegian and Swedish inflation data weighed on both Kronas whilst the RUB, TRY and HKD all benefiting from intervention to trade off worst levels.

content:
DXY

Ending a tough week off worst levels, but still below the 90.000 axis and considerably weaker than it was prior to last Friday’s NFP report that missed consensus on the headline payroll count by some distance. The China vs US import tariff stand-off, Syria and Russian sanctions have largely dominated risk sentiment and directed moves in the broad Dollar with little on the data front to provide impetus as CPI was more or less in line with consensus. Hawkish FOMC minutes did give the Greenback a relatively modest lift, but a charm offensive between the US President and his Chinese counterpart was arguably equally supportive (for the Greenback and improved investor appetite for risk in general). However, this all paled into comparison vs a Trump tweet alleviating concerns about an imminent strike against Syria, which was only partly offset by Russia unveiling a list of counter-sanctions vs the US. The index is currently around 89.800 vs a circa 89.355 low on Wednesday.

AUD/NZD/CAD

The Aud is Friday’s stand-out commodity bloc and G10 outperformer, but all 3 have been big net winners on the week on a mixture of the aforementioned improving risk climate, data and CB leads, plus flows and re-positioning. Aud/Usd eventually hurdled some major barriers in the high 0.7700s, with stops tripped above 0.7780 to a multi-week high just shy of 0.7810 and the next upside tech levels from 0.7812-15 (former a Fib and latter the 200 DMA). The Kiwi has challenged resistance at the psychological 0.7400 level several times, and got closest when the Aud/Nzd cross slipped under 1.0500 amidst the height of US-China trade tensions, but has pulled back amidst the Aud short squeeze and paring back of heavily oversold positions. However, the Loonie has starred overall this week, with Usd/Cad down from almost 1.2820 on Monday to around 1.2550 at one stage on positive NAFTA deal prospects, some firmer than forecast data, an upbeat BoC business survey and sharp rally in oil prices. However, the BoC is not expected to be prompted into (hike) action as soon as next week.

GBP

The bullish April story continues, but Sterling also got a boost from BoE hawk McCafferty who underscored his dissenting vote for a hike with a warning to the MPC not to delay any further, as expectations for a 2nd tightening in May topped 90%. The Pound also received some good news on the Brexit front via reports that EU’s Barnier could be will to offer the UK more flexibility on the timing to agree transition terms. Cable almost hit 1.4300 vs the 2018 high so far at 1.4345, while Eur/Gbp finally breached 0.8700 to trade down to 0.8625 or thereabouts.

EUR

A bearish week for the single currency overall vs major rivals, and largely due to dovish/cautious ECB minutes that more than counterbalance the hawkish lone or at least personal view of Nowotny. Eur/Usd faded after a few attempts at 1.2400 and needs to close above the 21 DMA at 1.2323 to avoid re-visiting recent lows on the 1.2200 handle.

JPY/CHF

Mixed fortunes, but with Usd/Jpy rallying through the key 107.50-55 area that has been capping the pair and threatening 107.90 resistance before 108.00. Usd/Chf and Eur/Chf also on an upward trajectory, though the Franc remains decoupled from usual/traditional safe-haven and risk correlations amidst capital outflows (Russian repatriation touted) and spec about official intervention.

SEK/NOK

Softer than forecast Norwegian and Swedish inflation data weighed on both Kronas.

EM

The Rub, Try and HKD all benefiting from intervention to trade off worst levels.

13th April 2018

Russian lawmakers have proposed banning US goods, this includes Tobacco, Alcohol, software, agriculture and medicine. (Newswires)

Earnings

  • Citigroup Inc (C) Q4 EPS USD 1.68 vs. Exp. USD 1.61, revenue USD 18.87bln vs. Exp. USD 18.86bln, Fixed income market revenue down 7% in Q1 to USD 3.4bln, Equity revenue up 38% to USD 1.1bln. (Newswires)
  • First Horizon (FHI) Q1 Adj. EPS USD 0.34 vs. Exp. USD 0.31, revenue USD 437mln vs. Exp. USD 441mln. Net Interest Margin at 3.43% vs. Prev. 2.92%. (Newswires)
  • First Republic (FRC) Q1 EPS USD 1.13 vs Exp. USD 1.07, revenue USD 720.9mln vs Exp. USD 733.96mln. (Newswires)
  • JPMorgan Chase & Co (JPM) Q1 EPS USD 2.37 vs. Exp. USD 2.28, revenue USD 28.5bln vs. Exp. USD 27.68bln. Fixed sales and trading revenue USD 4.55bln vs Exp. USD 4.44bln. Affirms FY18 Net Interest Income at USD 54 – USD 55bln. (Newswires)
  • PNC Financial Services Group Inc (PNC) Q1 diluted EPS USD 2.43 vs. Exp. USD 2.43, revenue USD 4.10bln vs. Exp. USD 4.16bln. (Newswires)
  • Wells Fargo (WFC) Q1 EPS USD 1.12 vs. Exp. USD 1.06, Revenue USD 21.9bln vs. Exp. USD 21.73bln. (Newswires)
  • Zillow (ZG) Q1 preliminary revenue USD 1.34bln-1.58bln vs. Exp. USD 1.31bln. The co. plans to expand its operation in Phoenix and collaborating with Premier Agent in selling homes in Las Vegas. (Newswires)

DJIA

  • Boeing (BA) – The aircraft manufacturer is in new talks with Embraer (ERJ) to form a new company which will focus on commercial aviation. Separately, Russia may ban exports of Titanium to the company. Also, Rolls Royce (RR LN) cautioned that it would ask for more money and inspections to fix problem with Trent 1000 engines on the jet manufacturers 787 dream liners noting there are problems with turbine blades wearing too quickly. Further, the FAA is to reduce its MAX single engine flying time for Rolls Royce, and the FAA has increased its inspections on the Trent 1000 engines. (Newswires)
  • Caterpillar (CAT) – The co. announced changes to the board to be effective from June 1st, after Group President Rob Charter is to retire. (Newswires)
  • Exxon Mobil (XOM) – The co. has restarted production of liquified natural gas in Papua New Guinea, which was temporary halted due to a severe earthquake on Feb. 26th. (Newswires)
  • Microsoft (MSFT) – The tech giant is investigating methods KPMG used to crack down on the illegal use of its software in India, following a complaint from a senior member of the ruling Indian political party. (Newswires)
  • General Electric (GE) / Morgan Stanley (MS) – The two companies are to work together to evaluate energy saving opportunities. (Newswires)

S&P500

  • Alaska Airline (ALK) – March traffic up 6.5%, capacity increased by 7.2% and load factors -0.5% (Newswires)
  • Allergan (ALG) – The co. announced the launch of its TrueTear, the only FDA cleared device to temporarily increase tear production in adult patients. (Newswires)
  • AT&T (T) / Time Warner (TWX) – A testimony on Wednesday from an economist said, “The proposed merger between the two would save consumers money as it would create a more efficient company”. (Newswires)
  • Ford (F) – The automaker reports China sales for March -11% to 83,666 vehicles vs. -30% in Feb. Jan-Mar vehicles sales -19% vs. -21% last year. (Newswires)
  • General Motors (GM) – The automaker confirms April 20th as the deadline for the restructuring programme in the Korean division. If it does not meet the deadline, it will likely file for bankruptcy protection. (Newswires)
  • Lockheed Martin (LMT) – A pentagon spokesperson said the F-35 pause is well on its way to being resolved. (Newswires)
  • Newell Brands (NWL) – The co.’s Waddington division have said to attract bidders including Novolex. (Newswires)
  • Range Resources (RRC) – COO Ray Walker to retire on April 13th. (Newswires)
  • Sempra Energy (SRE) – The co. announced to launch a liquid fuels marine terminal in Baja California. (Newswires)
  • Valero (VLO) – The co acquired the SemLogistic division from SemGroup. (Newswires)

NASDAQ 100

  • Alphabet (GOOGL) – The tech giant is chasing the Pentagon’s JEDI contract worth over USD 10bln fearing a revolt from workers and facing competition over the project with Amazon (AMZN), Microsoft (MSFT) and Oracle (ORCL). (Newswires)
  • Amazon (AMZN) – US President Trump asked for a task force to be created in order to study the US Postal Service and its financial difficulties, following claims that the retail giant was costing them money. (Newswires)
  • Alphabet (GOOGL)/Facebook (F)/Twitter (TWTR)/Snapchat (S) – The US senators proposed laws on data privacy for users’ data which enables user recourse if data is breached. (Newswires)
  • Broadcom (AVGO) – The chipmaker announced a USD 12bln stock buyback. (Newswires)
  • Electronic Arts (EA) – The co. has introduced new roles in addition to the executive team. (Newswires)
  • Facebook (F) – CEO Zuckerberg has been asked to testify again in front of EU regulators. The social media network does not anticipate revenues to be impacted by privacy concerns. Separately, the EU Commissioner Sandberg reported to have had constructive talks with the social platform over Cambridge Analytica’s scandal. (WSJ / Newswires)
  • Mylan (MYL) – The drug maker is in advanced talks to acquire Merck KGaA’s (MRK GY) consumer health business, following other bidders who did not suffice to the German company’s standards. Sources stated the two were negotiating around a USD 3.5bln price, however there is no certainty the deal will fall through. (Newswires)
  • Qualcomm (QCOM) – Chairman Paul Jacobs is reportedly looking to make the chipmaker private in the next two months, according to people familiar with the matter. Additionally, the co. has extended its cash offer for all the outstanding shares of NXP Semiconductors (NXPI) to April 20th. (CNBC / Newswires)

  • Sinclair Broadcasting Group (SBGI) / Tribune Media (TRCO) – Twelve US Senators have requested the US FCC investigate SBGI for “deliberately distorting news” and asked the commission to halt its ongoing review of its USD 3.9bln proposed acquisition of TRCO. (Newswires)
  • SeaWorld (SEAS) – The co. is likely to face SEC claims over misleading investors. (Newswires)
  • Rite Aid (RAD) – The shareholders of the co. are to oppose Albertsons merger as they believe it undervalues the co. (WSJ)

subject: Total Port Arthur refinery in Texas reports gas and crude units are running at full operation
Fed's Rosengren (non-voter, hawk) says somewhat more tightening than FOMC forecasts suggest might be needed
content:
• Rosengren: Inflation likely to increase a bit more than the current median FOMC forecasts, will reach then exceed target gradually
  • Rosengren: Labor markets are tight, may tighten more than FOMC forecasts project, wages have been rising gradually
  • Rosengren: Unlikely that the economy would perform poorly in near term; monetary and fiscal policy remain accommodative, but accommodation may generate risks in long term
  • Rosengren: By using up so much fiscal capacity now, US risks not having sufficient fiscal capacity in the future when it might be needed, would be troubling if monetary policy could not aggressively offset adverse shocks.
  • Rosengren notes forecasts are imperfect and not a promise; contingent on trade developments, international monetary policy, OPEC 
  • Rosengren: Short-term risks include international trade, and an overheating economy
  • Rosengren believes it would take a significantly broader set of trade actions than those reported to materially reduce US exports, but spillover effects are possible
  • Rosengren: Trend falling import prices due to strong dollar appears to be changing more recently
  • Rosengren: Long-term risks include reduced capacity of both fiscal and monetary policy to act against downturns
  • Rosengren: Fed has been falling short of inflation goal due to the decline in the relative price of imports from 2014-2016, and the decline in telecommunications prices in early 2017
  • Rosengren says spreads between corporate bonds and 10-yr Treasuries has fallen to relatively low levels, notes studies have showing investor confidence that generates low credit spreads often precedes subsequent economic reversals
  • Rosengren says FOMC outlook is fairly optimistic, but his outlook is firmer
  • Rosengren: Fed's long-term interest rate forecast low by historical standards due to demographics slowing labour force growth and productivity
analysis_details:
• Rosengren has previously hinted he is in the four-hike camp; FOMC median projections (March) pencilled in three hikes in 2018
  • Rosengren's own economic forecast calls for an even more pronounced decline in the unemployment rate, given his expectation that cyclical strength in labour force participation will provide only a partial offset to solid gains inpayrolls
  • Rosengren is optimistic, but warns the Fed must consider risks to the outlook

Daily US Opening News: 13th April 2018 - Now available in the Research Suite
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can no do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

13th April 2018

  • Syrian tensions and Russian sanctions the key focus as markets await further direction from Trump
  • Cable and AUD showing strong bids, as risk currencies lose and safe havens bid out
  • Looking ahead Uni. of Michigan, Fed’s Rosengren, Bullard and Kaplan, JP Morgan, Wells Fargo and Citigroup earnings

ASIA

Asian equity markets were mostly higher as the region partially took cue from Wall St, where sentiment was underpinned after US President Trump tweets further alleviated fears of an imminent strike on Syria. This resulted to firm gains across all US major indices, while the financial sector outperformed as yields rose in the wake of the recent hawkish FOMC minutes. As such ASX 200 (+0.3%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.6%) were positive with Australian financials mostly kept afloat following an upbeat Financial Stability Review, while Japan benefitted from the weaker currency-heightened risk dynamic. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (Unch.) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.4%) were underpinned at the open but then pared gains as the risk tone deteriorated following disappointing Chinese trade data and a CNY 100bln net weekly drain by the PBoC, while the White House was also reported to be planning to escalate trade pressure on China.

HKMA intervened in FX markets again and was said to have purchased HKD 2.44bln to support HKD in defence of the peg. (Newswires)

TRADE WARS

White House is planning to increase trade pressure on China, according to reports in WSJ, additionally US Trade Representative will detail list of goods as early as next week that may be subject to 25% tariffs as part of possible USD 100bln of additional tariffs on China, according to reports in WSJ. (Newswires)

Russian lawmakers have drafted legislation for sanctions on US goods including Tobacco, agriculture, medicine and consultancy. US equity futures held strong on this news. (Newswires)

CENTRAL BANKS

Barclays says it sees ECB to signal a slight downgrade to outlook for this year at the meeting later this month. (Newswires)

Fed's Kashkari (Non-Voter, Dove) repeats has not seen much wage growth nationally

Riksbank's Floden says the central bank should wind down most of its government bonds when monetary policy is normalised; adding that asset purchases may still be needed in the future, also says they are not trying to work for a weaker Krona

ECB's Smets says weaker inflation is still a lingering concern

GEOPOLITICAL

UK PM May and US President Trump spoke on Thursday and agreed it was vital to deter the further use by Syrian government of chemicals weapons, say that chemical weapons use must not go unchallenged. (Newswires)

Twitter source report US President Trump put off his final decision regarding strikes on Syria after meeting with security advisers, amid internal conflict with US Secretary of Defense Mattis and National Security Adviser Bolton. (Newswires)

EU/UK/US

Twitter sources noted that Trump administration to send spending cancellation proposal early next month in an effort to reduce some of the spending agreed to last month in the omnibus package, although senior GOP sources are said to be sceptical. (Newswires)

Japanese Finance Minister Aso says still investigating the Moritomo issue and that he welcomes US President Trump's comments on TPP if they are true. (Newswires)

Former FBI Director Comey new book excerpts state it is possible President Trump sought to obstruct justice. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

Equities trade modestly higher (Stoxx 600 +0.3%). This is largely due to the US (at the time of writing) having taken no decision on what (if any) military action should be taken on Syria with today's light calendar also failing to provide any major impetus for stocks. As such, moves have largely been noted in individual stock rather than broader based macro ones with equities resilient against new Russian sanctions vs. the US. Individual movers include Sage Group (-13%) after cutting guidance, Hammerson (-12%) are also lower after Klepierre’s (+1%) withdrawal of their acquisition offer. Finally, Volkswagen shares up 1.0% after their current CEO is to be replaced by Diess, who will be responsible for group research. (Newswires)

FX

AUD

No sign of contagion or concern over a surprise Chinese trade deficit despite the ongoing import tariff spat with the US, as Aud/Usd finally broke through major chart resistance around 0.7785 and triggered stops to probe just above 0.7800 before running out of steam ahead of a fib at 0.7812 and the 200 DMA at 0.7815.

NZD

Kiwi also firmer vs the Usd and nudging up towards 0.7400 again, but lagging its antipodean peer as the Aud/Nzd cross rebounds from just below 1.0500 to 1.0550+ on Aud short covering from a more oversold base.

GBP

Another G10 outperformer, with Cable almost up to 1.4300 having breached the recent 1.4244-50 range high and now looking at the 1.4345 ytd peak if the nearest big figure is taken out. On that note, further Eur/Gbp selling could give the Pound another boost with market contacts hearing talk of decent demand for downside option strikes and little in the way of technical support before 0.8600.

JPY

Still lagging amongst majors and the main victim of less aversion/tension surrounding trade wars and Syria (for now at least), with Usd/Jpy up through the 107.50-55 zone, which marked the top of late and included a fib level, before tripping some buy orders above 107.60.

CHF

Choppy trade in the Franc, with Usd/Chf higher early in the EU session and eyeing the 200DMA at 0.9650-60 amidst speculation about Russian outflows, but back down towards 0.9600 as Russia unveils counter-sanctions vs the US.

DXY

Just about maintaining positive momentum above 89.500 with more support coming from US President Trump who is now open to re-joining the TPP, if the terms are favourable, and is still holding off from any strike against Syria to assess chemical attack evidence.

CAD

The Loonie has recouped data-related losses and more to retest recent highs vs the Usd close to 1.2550 amidst more constructive NAFTA reports, and could get a helping hand from cross positioning as a big US bank implements a short Chf/Cad trade.

EUR

Extended weakness vs Sterling aside, the single currency remains rangebound vs the Usd between 1.2300-1.2350.

FIXED INCOME

Core EU bonds have recovered relatively well from the depths seen earlier on Eurex and Liffe when losses for the 10 year benchmarks reached 34 and 36 ticks in Bunds and Gilts respectively. Technicals may have been a catalyst for the turned around as nearest downside supports/targets held, while from a fundamental perspective Russia’s retaliatory moves vs US sanctions could have rattled a few nerves that were calmer on the cooling off in US-Chinese trade tensions (for the time being). It’s probably too premature, but some pre-weekend position squaring and paring is also feasible, or simply a few intraday traders/specs taking a few chips off the table ahead of the US open. Suffice to say that Bunds have revisited very early session highs (159.31) and Gilts have gone a step further to post a fresh peak (121.93, just 4 ticks below the previous close). US Treasuries mildly firmer and just a few ticks shy of best levels seen overnight, with the curve re-flattening after the 30 year auction drew the best results.

COMMODITIES

Looking at the commodities complex, WTI (+0.8%) and Brent (+0.8%) are setting new weekly highs, as ongoing tensions over Syria fuel the rally. This follows initial reports that the US was planning to strike 8 targets in Syria, but traders are mindful that US Press Secretary Sanders said no final decision was made. Furthermore, the UK cabinet backed military action against Syria. Elsewhere, the IEA monthly oil market report highlighted forecasts for 2018 global oil demand growth to remain unchanged from the prior month’s report of 1.5mln bpd. Moving onto metals, Gold (+0.1%) is marginally higher as the yellow metal tracks dollar weakness. In terms of base metals, copper (+0.6%) is higher on the day, however, the upside is capped by disappointing Chinese trade data. Aluminium (+13.8% this week) set for its best week since 1987 amid rising concerns of supply disruptions regarding Russian sanctions.

Gilts extending losses and underperformance, Short Sterling also on the back foot
content: UK debt and STIR futures under pressure, as Gilts continue to underperform against the backdrop of high/rising May BoE rate hike expectations, positive Brexit impulses, bearish positioning/technical and less risk-averse global sentiment overall. The core bond gapped down 8 ticks on its return to Liffe and then succumbed to more pronounced downside pressure to hit a 121.66 base, 33 ticks below Thursday close. Sellers/shorts will now be eyeing nearest chart support at 121.44, while the obvious objective for cash traders is 1.50% for the 10 year benchmark yield, which is not far from circa 1.472% at present. Short Sterling contracts down 1-2 ticks, bar Jun18 that is just a tick adrift. Back to fixed, Bunds are also extending losses and testing buying interest around 159.00 (158.99 base just printed, -30 ticks), which could clear the way to challenge last week’s 158.89 Eurex low if breached convincingly and expose stops set below.

Bunds: modest slippage after early uptick
content: A rather inauspicious start to Friday’s Eurex session, as the 10 year German benchmark opened completely flat at 159.29 and then attempted to tick higher, but only managed to hit 159.31 before hitting the buffers and retreating to a 159.21 low (-8 ticks). The ongoing, tentative recovery in risk sentiment on easing global trade and geopolitical tensions has quelled some demand for safe-haven bonds, but ranges remain tight/intact amidst underlying bids and a buffer in case US-China/Russia/Syria relations take another turn for the worse.  Bunds and Eurozone paper in general also benefiting from the ECB’s QE back-stop and relative policy accommodation vs the Fed and BoE that are firmly on the exit path.

content:
13th April 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets were mostly higher as the region partially took cue from Wall St, where sentiment was underpinned after US President Trump tweets further alleviated fears of an imminent strike on Syria. This resulted to firm gains across all US major indices, while the financial sector outperformed as yields rose in the wake of the recent hawkish FOMC minutes. As such ASX 200 (+0.3%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.6%) were positive with Australian financials mostly kept afloat following an upbeat Financial Stability Review, while Japan benefitted from the weaker currency-heightened risk dynamic. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (Unch.) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.4%) were underpinned at the open but then pared gains as the risk tone deteriorated following disappointing Chinese trade data and a CNY 100bln net weekly drain by the PBoC, while the White House was also reported to be planning to escalate trade pressure on China.

* EQUITIES: SPX +0.83% at 2664, NDX +1.11% at 6656 , DJI +1.21% at 24483 

SECTORS: CONS CYC (XLY): +0.45%, CONS NON-CYC (XLP): -0.19%, ENERGY (XLE): -0.01%, FINANCIALS (XLF): +1.82%, HEALTH CARE (XLV): +0.64%, INDUSTRIALS (XLI): +1.45%, MATERIALS (XLB): +1.07%, TECH (XLK): +1.29%, TELECOMS (XTL): -0.03%, UTLITIES (XLU): -1.28%. 

US equity futures traded higher on Thursday trade, boosted in the morning by US President Trump’s tweets, which put some Syrian tensions to ease. Futures also jumped at the US cash open and carried on the upward trend for most of the session, until reports suggested that the US is planning to strike eight targets in Syria (however this was never officially confirmed) and the markets resumed the buying trend. The S&P was led by Incyte (INCY) and MGM Resorts (MGM), INCY were upgraded to buy from neutral at UBS, and MGM were supported by reports from WSJ that it is in early talks to purchase Wynn Resorts’ (WYNN) Boston-area Casino Project. L-Brands (LB) lagged as the company’s PINK brand’s saw sales fall in March. McDonald’s (MCD) hampered the DJI today following reports which suggested workers in Kentucky may have spread Hepatitis A to some customers; and on the flip side, Intel (INTC) and Boeing (BA) led the DJI. In M&A news, Takeda (4502 JT) reportedly seeks several trillions of JPY worth of loans as it looks to acquire Shire (SHPG) which closed among the best performers in NDX. Also, General Electric (GE) are considering merging its units with other public companies, or an IPO or spinoff of its Transportation unit, as an alternative to asset sales. Later trade today saw rumours that Warren Buffet’s Berkshire Hathaway (BRK.A) was reportedly ready to make an announcement for the takeover of Southwest Airlines (LUV), which gave a boost to all airline names, which finished trade well in the green, however these reports were unconfirmed. On earnings front today also saw Blackrock (BLK) beating on both the top and bottom line sending them to close higher than 1.5%, combined with the higher yields today led to financials outperforming which finished Thursday trade higher by 2%. Delta earnings beat expectations, posting record revenues in the face of strong demand, though fuel and labour costs were rising. On Friday, JPM, Wells Fargo and Citi report numbers before the market open. JPM expected to report 2.28 eps on 27.7bln of revenue, Wells expected to report 1.06 eps on 21.7bln, and Citi expected to report 1.61 eps on revenues of 18.9bln.

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN OPENING NEWS: Asian equity markets were mostly higher as the region partially took cue from Wall St. after US President Trump dispelled fears over an imminent attack on Syria
content:
• Asian equity markets were mostly higher as the region partially took cue from Wall St. after US President Trump dispelled fears over an imminent attack on Syria
  • FX markets saw little in the way of sustained direction as the DXY somewhat maintained its gradual upward trajectory seen since FOMC minutes
  • Looking ahead, highlights include German CPI (F), Uni. Of Michigan, Fed’s Rosengren, Bullard and Kaplan

ASIA

Asian equity markets were mostly higher as the region partially took cue from Wall St, where sentiment was underpinned after US President Trump tweets further alleviated fears of an imminent strike on Syria. This resulted to firm gains across all US major indices, while the financial sector outperformed as yields rose in the wake of the recent hawkish FOMC minutes. As such ASX 200 (+0.3%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.6%) were positive with Australian financials mostly kept afloat following an upbeat Financial Stability Review, while Japan benefitted from the weaker currency-heightened risk dynamic. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (Unch.) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.4%) were underpinned at the open but then pared gains as the risk tone deteriorated following disappointing Chinese trade data and a CNY 100bln net weekly drain by the PBoC, while the White House was also reported to be planning to escalate trade pressure on China. Finally, 10yr JGBs were marginally softer with demand subdued by a positive tone seen in Japanese stocks, although downside was stemmed amid the BoJ’s presence in the market for JPY 840bln in maturities across the curve.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net weekly drain of CNY 100bln vs. last week's CNY 10bln net drain. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.2898 (Prev. 6.2834)

Monetary Authority of Singapore tightened policy through a slight appreciation of SGD NEER slope as expected. (Newswires)
MAS said domestic economy is likely to maintain steady expansion path this year and that upward pressures on core inflation is likely to persist past this year, although it also noted that an escalation of the US-China trade dispute remains possible which would have significant consequences for global trade.

Singapore GDP (Q1 A) Q/Q 1.4% vs. Exp. 1.2% (Prev. 2.1%). (Newswires)
Singapore GDP (Q1 A) Y/Y 4.3% vs. Exp. 4.3% (Prev. 3.6%)


UK/EU

Italy’s League leader Salvini said the centre-right wants to govern together with a PM chosen by the League. (Newswires)


FX

The majors were relatively inconclusive overnight in which the DXY somewhat maintained the gradual upward trajectory seen since this week’s hawkish FOMC minutes, while EUR/USD consolidated following the selling pressure that was triggered by cautious ECB minutes. GBP/USD took a breather after real money buying interest helped a reclaim of the 1.4200 handle on Thursday, while USD/JPY and JPY-crosses were propped up amid the overall risk-tone. Elsewhere, the HKMA authority continued to intervene and bought HKD 3.26bln in defence of the peg, while SGD initially strengthened after the MAS tightened its FX-based policy, although this was later pared as the decision was as expected and the central bank also suggested a cautiousness regarding the ongoing trade spat between US and China.

COMMODITIES

Commodities were mixed in which WTI crude futures pulled back below the USD 67.00/bbl as the geopolitical concerns, which had fuelled oil to levels last seen in 2014, took a back seat. Elsewhere, gold prices found some reprieve from the pressure seen since Wednesday’s hawkish FOMC minutes, while copper is indecisive following disappointing Chinese trade data which showed an unexpected trade deficit, surprise contraction in exports and a miss on imports.

China March iron ore imports fell 10% Y/Y to 85.8mln tons, while copper and copper product imports rose 2.1% Y/Y to 438k tons. (Newswires) 


GEOPOLITICAL

There were initial source reports that the US was planning to strike 8 targets in Syria. However, White House Press Secretary Sanders later said no final decision was made regarding Syria after President Trump finished meeting with his national security team. Furthermore, Twitter sources reported US President Trump put off his final decision regarding strikes on Syria in meeting with security advisers amid internal conflict between Secretary of Defense Mattis and National Security Advisor Bolton. (Newswires/Twitter)

UK PM May and US President Trump spoke on Thursday and agreed it was vital to deter the further use by Syrian government of chemicals weapons, while the leaders agreed to keep working closely on international response to Syria chemical weapons use and stated that chemical weapons use must not go unchallenged. (Newswires)

UK cabinet backed military action against Syria in which it agreed on the need to take action to alleviate humanitarian distress and to deter the further use of chemical weapons by Assad. (Newswires)

US Secretary of State nominee Pompeo said more work needs to be done on Russian sanctions as Putin has not yet received the message sufficiently, while he added that there is no sign Iran is racing towards a nuclear weapon and that there is 'long way to go' on North Korea even after talks. (Newswires)

European diplomat believes progress is being made towards Trump concerns on Iran’s nuclear deal. (Newswires)
 

US

US Treasury yields were higher on Thursday with short-dated yields up by 4bps and long-end yields up around 5bps by settlement, although most of the selling was in the belly of the curve. Selling pressure was seen pre-market after Trump’s tweet hinted that military action might not be in the offing. Even later in the session, when it emerged the US was close to military action, the Treasury complex struggled to catch a bid. The US completed this week’s supply offering with an auction of 30-year bonds, which stopped through the screens by 0.1bps, the strongest auction this week. Traders were encouraged by the direct bidders after the weakness seen this week, while indirects took down 61%, in line with recent averages. US 10yr T-Notes settle 12 ticks lower at 120-15.


White House is planning to increase trade pressure on China and the US Trade Representative will detail a list of goods as early as next week that may be subject to 25% tariffs as part of possible USD 100bln of additional tariffs on China. (WSJ)

US Special Counsel Mueller is said to be preparing a minimum of 4 findings to make case of obstruction of justice against US President Trump, while there were also reports that excerpts from former FBI Director Comey’s new book stated it is possible President Trump sought to obstruct justice (NBC/Newswires)

US Republican Senator Roberts said President Trump indicated in a meeting that he assigned NEC Director Kudlow, US Trade Representative Lightizer and other advisers to have another look at the Trans-Pacific Partnership. However, President Trump later noted that the US would only join TPP if deal was substantially better than what was offered to prior administration. (Newswires/Twitter)

Twitter sources noted that Trump administration is to send spending cancellation proposal early next month in an effort to reduce some of the spending agreed to in the omnibus package, although senior GOP sources are said to be sceptical. (Twitter)

US President Trump said to issue order related to task force to probe US postal system pricing on packages. (Newswires)

Fed's Kashkari (Non-Voter, Dove) repeated that he has not seen much wage growth nationally, while he added that the US must avert a trade war with China and that it is difficult to gauge where a trade dispute will end up. (Newswires)
